65.text:
Once again it's the end of January and
most people in the toy business head back to

69.text:
the Toy Fair at Nuremberg.   There are
special guards to keep out the uninvited.

73.text:
We will start at the BYMO stand and it's
noticeably smaller this year, and there is one

79.text:
model certainly worth a look and that is the big
Komatsu PC 8000 shovel.  It seems to have

85.text:
been under development for years, but
it's now getting close and it's expected

89.text:
that Komatsu will have it available
for the Bauma show in April.  Look at the

94.text: people flooding into the Toy Fair.   Hey mate! You are going the wrong way.  Next up is Motorart

101.text:
and the disappointing news for 2016 is
that there will be no new Volvo models,

106.text:
not even for the Bauma show.  So there
was only old stuff at the Motorart stand

111.text:
and all that is promised for the end of
the year is a couple of Kobelco

114.text:
excavators.   A new name at this year's Toy
Fair is IMC models and the people

121.text:
involved are essentially from what was Tonkin
Replicas Europe.   The new Scheuerle SPMT

126.text:
models were on display and this set up carrying
a TBM load looked particularly good.  Also

132.text:
new at the show were these SPMT split and scissors
modules.   Looking good and close to

137.text:
release are a couple of Nooteboom
ballast carriers and also interesting

142.text:
is a Nicolas  Euroflex semitrailer.
Also coming are a couple of Hyundai

146.text:
models in 1/87 scale, and plenty of coloured
trucks.

150.text:
There will also be a few more releases
for Bauma including one model that's

153.text:
physically very large, and IMC are also
busy on some Terex cranes.   Another new

159.text:
name at the Toy Fair was Start Scale
Models from Eastern Europe.  They were

163.text:
displayed a large range of diecast
models of Russian equipment and it's all

168.text:
made in China.  and in 1/43 scale.
Most of it is old timer stuff and it

174.text:
certainly looks interesting and unusual.
Some collectors did seem a little bit

179.text:
disappointed at the number of new
releases.   Yet another new name at the

185.text:
Toy Fair is Diecast Masters and they have
taken over the Cat license from Tonkin

190.text:
Replicas and Norscot.  Norscot might be
back with other things soon but the

195.text:
first difference that Diecast Masters
are making is with the packaging and all

199.text:
new models in their High Line series will
come in high quality metal tins, and that also

204.text:
includes some information about the real
machine. So let's open it up and see what

209.text:
it's like.   It's got a nicely fitting lid
and inside we see some foam rubber with

214.text:
a finger hole.   Let's stick my finger in and hope
there is nothing inside which bites, and

219.text:
when the high quality foam is eased out
we see the model is sitting inside.

222.text:
Something else knew from Diecast Masters
is that each model will have a figure

227.text:
inside.  Some will be fixed and some will
be removable.   A large number of new

231.text:
releases are planned and some of them
were available in prototype form at the

235.text:
Toy Fair and the first impressions are
good with certainly the newer ones

239.text:
looking to be of a higher standard
Caterpillar model than we've seen

242.text:
previously.  Diecast Masters have also said
with the higher quality packaging and

247.text:
models, that the final pricing will be no
higher than previous models.  So overall

253.text:
it looks like the change to Diecast
Masters will provide some new excitement

257.text:
and innovation into Caterpillar models.  In fact the 
innovation didn't stop there because two

262.text:
underground models will have electronic
lights.

266.text:
This kind of lighting has only been used
in a limited way before on construction

270.text:
models, so it'll be interesting to see if
this starts a trend and how is received

274.text:
in the market.   Many of the new releases that are
planned are expected to be available from

279.text:
March onwards, and if you want something
a little bit different

283.text:
this D11T will be available in a copper
finish.

298.text:
One of the usual exhibitors at the show
was NZG but it seems to follow

302.text:
the trend with a stand only half the
size of previous years. The number of new

307.text:
releases on show was fairly limited with
plenty of new Unimogs and that

312.text:
includes these rail mounted versions.
Alternatively if you want a bit of a

316.text:
lift there will be Unimogs with loader
cranes, and there will also be an

321.text:
agricultural version.  Also on display were
revised versions of machines by HBM and

326.text: Weycor but for NZG Bauma in April will be the interesting time with

331.text:
perhaps ten or more new models expected.
Something else on display at the NZG

336.text:
stand were accessories by Weiss Brothers and
that included their high-quality lifting

367.text:
Another exhibitor at the show was Air
Force 1 Models and despite its name it

375.text:
had a big display of construction of
models of Chinese equipment.  Many of

380.text:
these are in larger and more unusual
scales and they do provide something

385.text: different and interesting to look at.

392.text:
One thing that's nice at the Toy Fair is
that they serve food if you are hungry.

396.text:
Another of the longer term players at the
Toy Fair is WSI models and one thing

402.text:
unusual at their stand was some prototype
car models, but of course there were

407.text:
plenty of high-quality crane models and
they were proudly displaying an award

411.text:
given to them by somebody or other.   WSI
recently announced they were moving into

416.text:
American trucks and the first
re-releases of the old Sword Models line

420.text:
was on display, but new was a 3+1
arrangement for Nooteboom and an updated

427.text:
Also coming is a line of classic Volvo
truck models.   Also on the WSI stand was a

435.text:
display by Drake Collectibles and this
line of models of Australian trucks and

440.text:
trailers is really setting the pace.   Just
released is the new Drake Steerable Low

446.text:
Loader and the first impressions are the
presentation is top quality.   Not only

451.text:
that but the model inside doesn't look
like it will disappoint with some high

456.text:
functionality and great detailing.  Even
existing models like the big C509

461.text:
are getting enhancements with revised tooling allowing
the coiled lines to be kept tidy, and

467.text:
there are other alternate variations too.  Coming
close to release is this MaxiTrans freight

472.text:
trailer and it also looks to be of a
high standard with all the gates being

478.text:
made out of metal.   Of course in
Australia the trucks go large and it

484.text:
will be possible to configure some
seriously impressive truck models.

499.text: One company not at the Toy Fair this year was Conrad Models,

503.text:
but their factory
is nearby to Nuremberg so they decided to hold

507.text:
an event there instead of at the show.
There was a display case  full of

512.text:
the releases so far announced for 2016,
but before looking at those we will look at

519.text:
Conrad has a museum charting its
products from when it started in 1956

523.text:
and on display are around 1500 models
from the last sixty years or so.  This

530.text:
museum is well worth a visit and it's
possible to do so by making prior

534.text:
arrangement with Conrad Models, and in
June 2016 they will hold an open day event to

540.text:
celebrate their 60th anniversary.   The
display cases are packed full of

545.text:
interesting models and probably some of
them you never even knew existed. In

549.text:
addition to construction models there is
fire trucks and lots of different

553.text:
forklifts.   Moving on to the 2016 models
there is a large number of trucks including

559.text:
this very impressive big Palfinger loader
crane model.  As with the other model

564.text:
makers there was not too many new construction
models on display and again that's

569.text:
because in April there will be a number
of new models released for the Bauma

572.text:
exhibition.   Among the trucks there are a
number of castings using the new Arocs cab

577.text: and there is also a new towed trailer model.

580.text:
The
2016 show was interesting for a number

584.text:
of reasons.  Although Conrad were not  there
and others had downsized, new arrivals

590.text:
such as Diecast Masters and IMC Models
are something to look forward to and you

595.text:
can expect many more construction models to
be seen at the Bauma exhibition in 2016.
